Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Can finite verbs agree in number with the nominal object?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Are there cases that do not show agreement in terms of case?
Comment: In attributive clauses the modifyer has no case/number marker.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can adpositions be used to mark non-core/oblique verbal arguments?
Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (S/A) marking?
Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (P) marking?
Do characteristics of object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does the marking of the object depend on the verb conjugation form?
Is there differential subject marking?
Comment: The subject is in the dative in necessive constructions.

Name: Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Is there a grammatical device for habituality?
Comment: PST2 expresses habituality.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for frequentative?
Is there a grammatical device for progressivity?
Comment: In addition to expressing repeated events, PST2 can also express events that were continuing in the past.

Name: Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Comment: The forms of present cover both present and future time reference.

Name: Is there a grammatical device for immediate future?
Is there a grammatical device for pluperfect?
Can aspect be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Comment: Aspectual oppositions can be expressed with the objective vs. subjective conjugation. In the past tense, the negative marker takes person marking, and the two conjugation types are differentiated in the negative marker.

Name: Can tense be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking for irrealis (e.g. hypothetical state of affairs)?
Are verbs marked in a specific mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Comment: The infinitive-participle -ma can mark necessity. The subject has to be in the dative case in this construction.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Comment: The passive/reflexive marker v is used to express capability, possibility, passive voice (depending on a context).

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 3Sg?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 1Sg?
Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there reflexive conjugation?
Comment: There is no reflexive conjugation, there is only the passive/reflexive marker v, e.g. käd'-ǝn-za tapa-v-s't' (hand-PL-POSS.3SG break-PASS-PST1.3PL) 'his/her hands got broken'

Name: Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Comment: However, verbs like 'feed' and 'give drink' can take two objects, one in the ablative and the other one in the nominative/genitive, e.g. andǝ-maz' jam-da (feed-3PL>1SG porridge-ABL) 'They fed me with porridge'.

Name: Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Comment: In Moksha, 2nd and 3rd person plural is always distinguished: kunda-samas't' (catch-PRS.2PL>1SG/1PL) 'you catch me/us' and kunda-samaz' (catch-PRS.3PL>1SG/1PL) 'they catch me/us'.

Name: Can an impersonal (or passive) form be used instead of a finite plural form with an overt subject expression?
Can third person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Can second person singular verb forms be used in generic meaning?
Are clauses with only infinitive predicates possible?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in bare infinitive form?
Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments (e.g. weather verbs)?
Is copula needed for predicate nominals in the 3rd person form of the present tense?
Comment: The copula is covert: son mokšа (3SG.NOM Moksha) 's/he is a Moksha'.

Name: Is a copula needed for predicate nominals in the past and/or future tense?
Comment: The copula in the present tense has future reference.  In the past tense, it is possible to use the copula with predicate nominals, but predicate nominals can also be conjugated in the second past tense: Mar'a stir'-ks mazije-l' (Mary girl-TRA beautiful-PST2.3SG) Mary was beautiful as a girl.

Name: Can locative adverbial phrases act as predicates without a copula?
Comment: In other persons the locative adverbial gets verbal endings: Mon kud-s-an (1SG house-INE-1SG) 'I am at home'.

Name: Can the same coordinating conjunction be used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Comment: It is possible to use the same coordinating conjunction in all cases, though with nouns different types of coordinating is also possible: t'äd'ä-t-s't'iR'-t' (mother-PL.NOM-girl-PL.NOM) 'mothers and daughters'.

Name: Does existential negation have a separate operator?
Comment: In existential sentences, the negation particle aš is used. In other sentences, the negation particle af is used in the present tense and the negation verb iz'- or aš- (which conjugates according to person) in the past tense.

Name: Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Comment: In the present tense, negation is symmetric, e.g. koRt-an : af koRt-an (speak-PRS.1SG : NEG speak-PRS.1SG) 'I speak : I don't speak'.

Name: Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Comment: Participle and gerund forms are negated with the negative construction apak + connegative (in Moksha the connegative with the participle apak ends in k, similar to the imperative of the 2nd person singular), instead of other constructions used with finite verbs.

Name: Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Are there nonfinite forms specialized on the relativization of particular core participants, e.g. subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials, instruments, etc.?
Comment: See also UT055.

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials or instruments, but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants, e.g. subjects?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Is there a future participle?
Are there participles that can encode their subject by possessive suffixes?
Can subject in at least some participial subordinate clauses be encoded in the same way as in independent clauses?
Are there participles that obligatorily agree with the nouns they modify in case and number (in all contexts)?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs without any additional morphological material, such as case markers?
Comment: The past participle and the gerund are syncretic only in the negated forms. In affirmative forms, there are different endings for the past participle and the gerund.

Name: Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Comment: saJ-t' mar' (take-IMP.2SG apple) 'Take an apple'.

Name: Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Comment: It is possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb, but it is not very common.

Name: Are there preverbs?
Are there verbal prefixes?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalization in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Can the modifier of action nominalization in patient role (e.g. "drinking of coffee") be encoded like the direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Is it possible to form synthetic superlative?
Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Are there separate adpositions to express goal, source, and location (without there being syncretism)?
Is case compounding possible?
Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Comment: It is possible to use either the nominative or the ablative with numerals.

Name: Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals bigger than 1?
Comment: Both the singular and the plural is possible with numerals bigger than 1.

Name: Is there a genitive case that has an affix?
Is there a case used to express indirect object/receiver/goal (different from a local case)?
Is there a terminative case?
Is there a separate case to indicate without what/who an action takes place / does not take place?
Comment: The abessive can be used as a case-ending or in an adnominal function as an adjective. The latter function might be more frequent. Therefore, the abessive is not considered as a case-ending in most of the grammars.

Name: Is there a separate case to mark the motion along or by the referent of the noun (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that marks goal?
Is there a locative case that marks location?
Is there a locative case that marks source?
Is there case syncretism of goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism of location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Is there a third set of local cases?
Is there a separate case for marking the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Comment: The inessive -sa expresses the instrumental as well: mašina-sa (car-INE) 'with a car'.

Name: Is there a separate case for marking accompaniment, which is different from the instrumental?
Is there a separate case for marking the result of change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Is there a separate case for marking the state of being (essive), which is different from the translative?
Is there a separate morphological marker for expressing equative meaning?
Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Comment: The dative is used (see UT082).

Name: Is there in addition to the basic declension a declension different from a possessive declension?
Comment: Moksha has three declension types: basic declension, definite declension (expresses that the referent of the noun is known to the speaker and the listener) and the possessive declension.

Name: Is it possible to use singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Can 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Can 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Comment: The 3SG possessive suffix can be used instead of the definite declension with some unique nouns, however, this use is restricted.

Name: Is there human vs. non-human distinction distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
Comment: The pronoun kijä 'who' is not used frequently, but the kona 'who, that, which' is used instead. It appears with animates: loman'-c'/buka-s', kona sa-s' c'ej (person-DEF.NOM/ox-DEF.NOM that come-PST1.3SG here) 'The person/ox that came here' as well as with inanimates valks-s', kona lis'-s' mel'ä (dictionary-DEF.NOM which come.out-PST1.3SG) 'the dictionary that came out last year'.

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Comment: Kona 'who, that, which' is used with both animates and inanimates (see UT107).

Name: Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with 3rd person singular human referent?
Are there possessive suffixes whose position in relation to case/number suffixes can vary?
Comment: The possessive suffixes usually follow the case suffixes, except for the genitive and dative, which precede the possessive suffixes.

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes fixed across the paradigm the same?
Comment: Plural marking is used in the basic declension only in the nominative. In other cases, the singular and the plural is distinguished only in the definite declension. The singular is unmarked, whereas in the plural the plural suffix t : t' (sometimes just the voicelessness of the previous consonant) follows the noun, and it is followed by the definiteness marker and the case ending.

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relative for other relations than siblings?
Is there animacy distinction for both concepts 'new/young' and 'old'?
Comment: There is only distinction for 'old', i.e. tašta 'old (inanimate)', s'ir'ä 'old (animate)'.

Name: Is there distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' based on whether referring to weather or to temperature of objects?
Comment: There is only distinction for cold: kel'mä ved' 'cold water', ušǝ-sa jakšama (outside-INE cold) 'it is cold outdoors'.

Name: Is there contrastive length of consonants?
Is there contrastive length of vowels?
Is there contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Is there contrast in duration of geminate consonants?
Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Comment: See UT125.

Name: Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Comment: The variants of the emphatic particle (clitic), -ga, -ge, -ka, -ke, -vok, -nga 'even, too': mon-ga 'me, too' tend to have primary or secondary stress.

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Comment: The first syllable tends to be stressed if the word is uttered as a dictionary item; in speech, mostly disyllabic feet with a stressed and unstressed syllable alternate: MOn sǝrxk-An insAru. - Mon sƏrxk-an InsarU 'I will go to Insar'.

Name: Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Is there non-initial primary stress?
Comment: A tendency to stress the non-first syllable is noticeable in words with the high vowels i, u in the first syllable and the low vowels a, ä in a non-first syllable: śijÄ 'silver', kujA 'fat'. However, rhythmic initial-syllable stress functions in these words as well.

Name: Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there rising diphthongs?
Are there lowering diphthongs?
Is there qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there front high rounded vowel ü [y]?
Is there front midhigh rounded vowel ö [ø]?
Is there back high unrounded vowel ï [ɯ]?
Is there back midhigh unrounded vowel ë [ɤ]?
Is there back low round vowel [ɒ]?
Is there contrast between low and mid front vowels (ä [æ] vs. e [e])?
Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized dentals?
Are there palatalized labials and velars?
Comment: Before front vowels, labials and velars may be palatalized: ve 'night' > v'e, kev 'stone' > k'ev'.

Name: Is there palatal stop [c]?
Is there palatal nasal [ɲ]?
Is there palatal lateral [ʎ]?
Is there phonemic velar nasal [ŋ]?
Is there dental affricate [t͡s]?
Is there non-alveolar affricate (e.g. [t͡ʃ], [͡cɕ])?
Is there a phonological contrast between [s] and postalveolar sibilant [ʃ]?
Are there voiced plosives [b, g, d]?
Is there glottal stop [ˀ]?
Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
Is there a constraint on word-initial r?
Is there laryngeal fricative [h]?
Is there voiced velar fricative [ɣ]?
Is there voiceless velar fricative [x]?
Is there voiced dental fricative [ð]?
Is there phonemic labio-velar approximant [w]?
Is there voiceless labiodental fricative [f]?
Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
